availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects

note.p: NLS Adv. MS 72.2.2 is a late collection of fragments of various manuscripts. The original context of many of the fragments is not now apparent but they mostly seem to date from the 17th or 18th centuries. Classical Gaelic bardic poetry composed and/or inscribed by members of the Mac Mhuirich family predominates. Other genres are represented to varying extents. This transcription presents two formal panegyrics and two poems in looser metre and more informal subject-matter.

summary.p: Four poems are included in this transcription. 1 and 2 were inscribed by Eoghan mac Pháil (c. 1603), 3 by Domhnall Mac Mhuirich, and 4 by Niall Mac Mhuirich:

list.item: 'Goll mear mileat', in praise of Goll mac Morna, Finn mac Cumaill's legendary rival;
'An bfhaca tusa thu fein', a love poem;
'Maith an sgel do sgaoil nar miosg' (c. 1696), in praise of Ailin, Chief of Clanranald;
'Domhnall mac Raghnuill rosg mall' (13th-cent.?), in praise of Clann Domhnaill's eponymous ancestor.

summary.p: 3 and 4 have been chosen deliberately as specimens of late and early bardic poetry respectively.

msItem.title: Maith an chairt cennas na nGaoidheal

titleStmt.title: Maith an chairt cennas na nGaoidheal

note.p: The poem praises the martial and lordly virutes of Goll mac Morna, leader of a rival faction to that of Finn mac Cumaill within the Fian. It is mostly abstract and makes no explicit reference or even allusion to any incidents in Fenian tradition or to narrative context. Goll is named on a number of occasions, given his patronymic, and is called a "feinnuidh" (q16a). Otherwise, the poem remains impressionistic. The metre seems to be a loose form of lethrannaigecht mór, with a simplified rhyme scheme.

filiation.p: There are no other known versions of this poem. However, it is very similar in style and focus to 'Ard agni zwlle' ('Ardaigneach Goll') from BDL (pp.145–147; ed. and trans. Ross 1939: 60–68; trans. Bateman and McLeod 2007: 320–331) . 'Ard agni zwlle' is also in lethrannaigecht mór, although this time with the expected rhyme scheme, and consists of praise of Goll mac Morna in similar terms. However, this is framed within the laoidh as a plea on Goll's behalf by one Feargus File before Fionn mac Cumaill. This is evidently to be understood in the context of one of the disputes between Fionn and Goll (Flahive 2017), as the poem ends with Fionn agreeing that the praise of Goll is merited and that he will make peace with him. Indeed, one account of a conflict and resolution between these two heroes occurs in Bruidhean Beag na hAlmhaine, which is also written out by Eoghán Mac Pháil in the same original manuscript as 'Goll mear mileat' (NLS Adv. 72.1.34, pp. 25–38). Whether such a narrative context and outcome is to be understood for 'Goll mear mileat' is not clear. There is also no noticeable close textual correspondence in terms of shared lines or phrases. Nonetheless, the two texts are distinctly similar in other ways and are both preserved in Scottish manuscript contexts, suggesting that 'Goll mear mileat' might be particularly insightful in Scottish Fenian ballad tradition.

list.head: Vowels
list.item: ea and io are generally used instead of e and i;
ae is occasionally used in unstressed syllables where ea would be expected (e.g. q3a).
ao is generally used instead of ae.
On several occasions, a is used where e would be expected: enach is rendered "anach" (q21b) and cinedach is rendered "cíonadhaigh (q12b), for example.
Accents are only sometimes added where expected and sometimes appear where they are not expected (e.g. "cíonadhaigh (q12b).
In palatalised final syllables following a slender vowel, there is a strong tendency to spell the final vowel "-ui" (e.g. "dáoinuibh" (q6a); "fileadhuibh"(q12d)).
In one example, -éi- is represented as "-eidh-" and, in the same example, an epanthetic vowel is also added.

list.head: Consonants
list.item: Lenition of bilabial stop "b" is mostly shown but sometimes not (e.g. "fhogluib", q10c versus "fheaghuibh", q12c);
Lenition of dental and velar stops in final position is shown throughout.
There is one possible pronunciation spelling of a lenited final dental stop: "mugha", for mugadh (q19b).
Final resonant "-nn" (/N/) is written "-nn" throughout.
Voiceless velar fricatives (/x/) are favoured in place of voiced velar fricatives (/ɣ/) (e.g. "lamhachadh" (q5c; for lámugad)).

list.head: Initial Mutations
list.item: In the marking of eclipsis, nasalisation is only used with consonants that can take nasalisation in the earlier language (e.g. "nach gcainfithior" (q15b); "go ndeirbheile" (q14a)).
Lenition is not always marked (e.g. "beim guill glain" (q16d), "nar thraoth treuntacar" (q5d)).
For the lenition of initial "s", "t(h)-" is often prefixed, with or without the additional lenition of "s" itself (e.g. "thsaoir" (q21a); "thshleibhe" (q9c)).

list.head: Letter Forms
list.item: Eoghán Mac Pháil's hand, when he is writing in Gaelic, produces mostly very conventional corra litir.

His superscript and above-letter abbreviations and his end-of-line letter forms can have a pronounced flourish (e.g. MS7, fol. 7v10, 13. This is enabled by a relatively fullsome space being available on these folios.

list.head: Abbreviations
list.item: Abbreviations, suspensions, and contractions are conventional for pre-modern Gaelic manuscript.
Suspension strokes are only used to represent a single syllable, which is usually final.

list.head: Word Division
list.item: Word division mostly aligns with modern conceptions of word boundaries.
However, spaces are often placed between components of compound nouns and adjectives (e.g. fol. 7v12).

list.head: Verse Layout
list.item: Quatrains are laid out by one couplet to a manuscript line.
The lines in the couplet are separated by a space and sometimes a punctus.
A new quatrain is introduced with a large capital initial projected into the left-hand margin.

list.head: Punctuation and Capitalisation
list.item: Apart from the capitals and points used to indicate the metrical structure, no punctuation or capitalisation are used in this text.

list.head: Corrections
list.item: On one occasion, a word is added from above through use of a caret mark (fol. 7v11).
The scribe deletes a letter on one occasion in this text (fol. 7v22) by placing a dot beneath the letter.
On another occasion, the descender of an ar abbreviation has been rubbed out to correct it to an "-a" ("treunfheardh a"; fol. 7v21).
On the same line, to correct a pronunciation spelling, "fh" has been inserted by cramming it in between existing letters (fol. 7v21).

list.head: Nouns
list.item: Nouns that are neuter in the earlier language do not occur in contexts where it is possible to determine whether they are still being treated as neuters.
A paucity of verbs in the poem mean it is not possible to draw conclusions as to the use of the accusative for the object of the verb.
Prepositions that took the accusative in the earlier language take the dative in this text (e.g. q10c, q12d).
There is some preservation of dental stems (e.g. "biodhbadh" (q2b).
Dative plurals are regularly preserved throughout.

list.head: Adjectives
list.item: Despite this text containing a lot of adjectives, there are no examples of the comparative or the superlative.
All adjectives in the text appear to be being used to describe Goll, so no observations can be made about plural adjectives.

list.head: Articles
list.item: The definite article is always monosyllabic.
The neuter definite article is not used.

list.head: Verbs
list.item: Very few verbs appear in this poem: one isntance of the copula and four instances of other verbs.
All verbs that do appear (apart from verbal nouns and the copula) are in the negative.

All verbs other than the copula are used within relative constructions, meaning it is not possible to discern the respective preponderances of synthetic and analytic forms, although a system of verb endings appears to be being used.
q15 praises Goll twice as "an X that is not Yed", using a relative f-future (habitual) passive in each case (q15b and q15d).
The other two uses of verbs are statements praising Goll as "an X who has not Yed Z", each using the same negative past relative constuction (q3a and q5d).

In this past relative construction, ro is used, although embedded within nar; it is not clear if it is to be read as having perfective force, although one example seems to be in the imperfect tense (q3a).
One relative lenites (q5d); the other does not (q3a).

list.head: Verbal Nouns
list.item: Verbal nouns are used more plentifully.
A variety of endings are used (-áil (e.g. q2d), -adh (e.g. q18a), and -uin (e.g. q10a).
Very few pronouns, possessive_pronouns, or pronominals are used in the text; it is invariably focused on Goll by implication so these are usually unnecessary.
None of the verbs used involve infixed pronouns but there are two few verbs overall to draw strong conclusions about the verbal system.
The syntax of the poem is rarely complex; a line usually consists of a string of adjectives or a noun followed by adjectives.
Occasionally, the adjectives will precede the noun, as if with an implied copula (e.g. q22c).
prep. + verbal noun phrases can take the place of adjectives as descriptors (e.g. q19c).
As noted above, verbs are occasionally used in the relative, again as descriptors.
The vocabulary and imagery used in the poem are that of the discourse of traditional Gaelic panegyric.
A lot of the praise for Goll is about his literal virtues as warrior and king.
Some nature imagery is also used; for example, Goll is in several places compared to a river or to a sea (e.g. q10d, q19c).
There is no other noticeably technical vocabulary.
There are no particularly prominent or recent loanwords

note.p: 'Goll mear mileat' is in the sub-Classical language and style common to late medieval and early modern heroic laoidhe. Its language is heavily influenced by Classical standards and the metre an ógláchas version of the metres known from the fully formal poetry (Gunderloch 2013: 74; Flahive 2017: 32). The simple syntax and disconnected images combined with the looser metre make this a relatively undemanding poem.

There are no clear indications of Scottish versus Irish origin. The poem is also very difficult to date with precision. The absence of any Middle Gaelic stratum means it likely dates from after 1200 and the scribe was active at the beginning of the 17th century. The best date range available thus appears to be 1200×1600.

The poem is very much in the style of Gaelic panegyric, as used in the praise of historical subjects by professional poets. It largely consists of a rapid succession of images and general assertions, with very few developed statements or references and no narrative. Bateman and McLeod call the similar poem, 'Ard agni zwlle' ('Ardaigneach Goll'), "spirited" (2007: 321). Likewise, 'Goll mear mileat' is based around rapid fire, alliteterative images delivered in short, sharp metrical lines.

msItem.title: An bfhaca tusa thu fein
msItem.explicit: ... a gruaid oireadha ioghon AN FACA

note.p: 'An bfhaca tusa thu fein' is a love poem, addressed to a woman. It begins (qq1–7) with praise of her beauty. This section is fairly methodical, anatomically speaking, with roughly one line devoted to each body part. The speaker then asks why the addressee conceals her beauty, when (unrequited?) love for her could prove fatal (qq8–12). The final quatrain (q13) returns to praising her beauty. Overall, the poem expresses exasperation at the addressee not realising her own beauty. It is hinted that realisation of this would somehow cause her to requite the speaker's love, although rejection is not so prominent a theme.

filiation.p: No other text of this poem is known. However, it has much in common with the 'courtly love' genre that is well-represented in BDL and the Irish dánta grádha (Gillies 1977: 35–38). For example, love is presented as a sickness (e.g. q12a) and the beloved as otherworldly and unattainable (q11c).

msItem.title: Maith an sgel do sgaoil nar miosg
msItem.incipit: [prose pref.] A ainm a n athar agas an mhic ...

titleStmt.title: Maith an sgel do sgaoil nar miosg

msItem.title: Domhnall mac raghnuill rosg mall
msItem.explicit: ... ga huaim do snáithe ghlan ghlóir [aceph.?]

msItem.title: Coir freasdal ar feill na gras
msItem.incipit: Coir freasdal ar feill na gras ...

titleStmt.title: Coir freasdal ar feill na gras

note.p: While the literal meaning of Béinne Brit is "company of the Britons", one or more individuals called "Béinne Brit" appear in a number of texts as kings of the Britons.
Black understands this to be a form of the verb do-icc (0130323).

HDSG Slip 0021050 reads astardha, "swiftness". However, I cannot find this form attested elsewhere and its closest relative, astar, has a rather different meaning ("journey, labour"). For these reasons, the HDSG reading is rejected.

HDSG Slip 0100173 understands this as the genitive singular of las, "light". Domhnall is being praised as "swiftness of light" (see previous footnote). However, due to the problems with this reading of the previous word, this reading too is rejected.

HDSG slip 0120003 reads this as "sadarna" (Saturn). However, the spelling is unusual and the lenition of the following word is left unexplained (Saturn is masculine). An alternative reading has therefore been adopted.
Note that the translations of this line in the relevant HDSG slips vary from slip to slip.
McLeod and Bateman's emendation is supported by the version of this quatrain quoted in the IGT.

McLeod and Bateman (2007: 76-77) take "finn" as a reference to Finn mac Cumaill. As I am not aware of any tradition of Clann Domhnaill descending from Finn mac Cumaill, however, it is being taken here as simply an adjective.

The edge of the page runs right along the top of the letters in line 1, meaning some accents or abbreviation markers may have been lost. The most obviously required accents have been supplied. Only visible abbreviations are indicated.
HDSG Slip 0091129 does not translate this word but suggests an emendation to "iubhair". However, as whatever this is is compared to the yew in the next line, this does not seem likely.

HDSG Slip 0090218 reads this as prep. do, followed by the untranslated and otherwise unattested word, gian. Until more information is available regarding what this word is postulated to mean and whence it is meant to derive, this reading cannot be accepted.

l.w:
h ao
im h n
ar
as
